citations.narrative:
There is currently no identification system in place for the dogs at the facility which meets USDA APHIS requirements. All
dogs housed at the facility must be identified by one of the acceptable means described in section 2.50(a)(1). Dogs and
Puppies are being issued an identification number, however this ID number is only used on the official APHIS Forms
(7005 and 7006). Licensee needs to utilize a compliant system of ID such as an official tag, tattoo or microchip for each
dog. All animals must be identified by one of the following: 1) a collar that contains the letters USDA, a unique identifying
number, and the license number; 2) a tattoo approved by USDA; or 3) a microchip that can be scanned by the licensee.
*******Correct by Dec. 22, 2023

Two dog enclosures had areas where the solid flooring was crumbling and jagged. A hole was observed in the flooring
directly below the automatic water source in both enclosures. This could possibly allow the dogs feet to fall through and
potentially become injured. Primary enclosures for dogs must be kept in good repair. The licensee must correct this issue.
*********Correct by Dec. 12, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.50(a)(1) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
There is currently no identification system in place for the dogs at the facility which meets USDA APHIS requirements. All 
dogs housed at the facility must be identified by one of the acceptable means described in section 2.50(a)(1). Dogs and 
Puppies are being issued an identification number, however this ID number is only used on the official APHIS Forms 
(7005 and 7006). Licensee needs to utilize a compliant system of ID such as an official tag, tattoo or microchip for each 
dog. All animals must be identified by one of the following: 1) a collar that contains the letters USDA, a unique identifying 
number, and the license number; 2) a tattoo approved by USDA; or 3) a microchip that can be scanned by the licensee.  
*******Correct by Dec. 22, 2023 
3.6(a)(1) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Two dog enclosures had areas where the solid flooring was crumbling and jagged. A hole was observed in the flooring 
directly below the automatic water source in both enclosures. This could possibly allow the dogs feet to fall through and 
potentially become injured. Primary enclosures for dogs must be kept in good repair. The licensee must correct this issue.  
*********Correct by Dec. 12, 2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
